But the way GW has went with it's political correctness and catering to lefty activists, I don't want to give them any of my money anymore. The insane price hikes was bad enough. But i'm not about to let a company piss in my face only to pretend that it's raining too.

replies.author: @stevewingate3023
replies.text:
@sevenproxies4255 I concur with you 100%. I got into GW stuff back when Judge Dredd- the RPG was around (89, I think), long before they became a public company and started shafting their loyal customer base.
I've been into 40k since it was released, though rarely play it (time, etc...), and I'm fed up with the constant new editions and price-gouging. 
They long ago lost what made the company so appealing to me and have become a soul-less corporate entity, and I rarely buy directly from them.
Wokeness came knocking on their door, and that was it for me. I will not be lectured to by what's essentially a toy company.

replies.author: @sevenproxies4255
replies.text:
@stevewingate3023 It's ironic in a way. I like their creation. But part of me wants to see GW crumble due to the onslaught of 3D printing.

I applaud people who engage in miniature piracy and refuse to pay the exorbitant prices that GW think they can charge for toy soldiers.

Frankly, the sooner the lore ends up in the hands of a community of dedicated hobbyists and away from GW's corporate execs, the better.

3D printing has so much potential for the hobby too. And GW being stupid, don't even try to make any changes to their obsolete business model to keep up with the technological development.

replies.author: @stevewingate3023
replies.text:
@sevenproxies4255 Their pricing defies logic for sure. Although I don't encourage (or condone) piracy, I do think they've missed the boat where 3D printing is concerned.
They did the same with airbrush technology and other developments in the hobby.  
There's definitely a revolution happening in 3D printing, I play Star Wars: Legion and the proxy figures available for that system are way ahead of the official releases, and comparatively cheaper in some respects.
But then again, would you really want to pay ¬£20+ for an STL for one Space Marine from GW? 
Let's face it, they won't be giving them away.
GW will inevitably fall. They'll either decline to a point where they lose their market dominance, or they'll be bought out by another company that won't understand the I.P. and will irreversibly change the product for profit and alienate their target consumers (I'm looking at you Disney+).
Anyway, this is all speculation from a long-time wargamer lamenting the days when his hobby didn't equate to a second mortgage. üòÜ

replies.text:
the problem with such ideologically driven people is that it's hard to take them seriously.
It's the same with all ideologues, they mix a kernel of truth with a whole shitload of believable sounding bull shit.

I'm not so sure if porn is addictive per se, no more than say action movies are or watching fashion shows. To some people who very easily get into addictive patterns of behaviour maybe, but not to more stable individuals.

Of course the sexual gratification gained by masturbation can lead to a hormonal high that is extremely gratifying. And without access to a real life sexual partner pornography becomes a substitute gateway to achieving that. 
Which is why I think pornography has in fact a positive side. It MAY stop some people from seeking out sexual partners by force (iow, prevent some people from turning to rape). Of course it's very hard to gather useful statistics on that, how are you going to get a control group after all...

author: @-TriP-
text: Pornhub's loss of content wasn't because of "the scandal" -- that was a separate thing.  It was because they were hosting tons of copyrighted content from other premium sites, onlyfans leaks, etc. and the DMCA hammer came down.

replies.author: @doomsfear
replies.text: Both?

replies.author: @matthewlane
replies.text:
"Pornhub's loss of content wasn't because of "the scandal" -- that was a separate thing.  It was because they were hosting tons of copyrighted content from other premium sites, onlyfans leaks, etc. and the DMCA hammer came down."

Nope. 

The loss of of content was the direct result of a fundementalist (anti-lgbt) christian group called Exodus Cry lying about the content of Pornhub, because they have a major hate boner specifically for pornhub.

This resulted in a bullshit article being published in the NY Times, which repeated the lies & pointed the finger at Visa & Mastercard, which resulted in Visa & Mastercard pulling payment processing, as a face saving acts.

This resulted in the banking services essentiallyy holding the site to ransom, until it put in to place idiot measures that achieved nothing but making it harder for the site to function, which was the publically stated purpose put forward by Exodus Cry.

It had nothing to do with the GDP scandal, or copyrighted material, or anything else. It was straight up an attempt to use extra-legal force to punish a porn site for containing 100% legal porn.

replies.author: @KT-pv3kl
replies.text: Basically the credit card payment processors gave phub an ultimatum to remove any and all potential illicit content from the site or lose their payment processor so they essentially removed all content that wasn't verified by the big studios. I suspect the studios themselves also had a hand in urging the credit card companies to make such an ultimatum knowing full well that it will remove millions of hours of content that competes with their own.

replies.author: @-TriP-
replies.text: @KT-pv3kl yeah the "questionable" stuff (which I still think there was much less of than on other, smaller platforrms) made them tighten up their verification/screening process as a result of the payment processors making a stink (rightly so, for once) but that increased scrutiny was just the ammo the studios needed to get outside premium content removed from the site and discourage future independent uploaders.  It had a pretty wide-reaching effect as well, most of the big pr0n sites no longer host unpaid premium content if it's not an official "preview" even if they don't have a verification system in place.

replies.author: @matthewlane
replies.text:

replies.text: I don't doubt there is some truth in this, but people are complicated, and while they can be selfish, self-deceptive, and deceptive, virtually all also have a sense of right and wrong. Doing wrong results always has negative internal consequences. These consequences can take several forms and unfold in infinite variety. Sometimes it is intense self-loathing, loathing for men or women, or justification and rationalizing earlier bad choices. Sometimes there is a genuine break from the old life. Unfortunately, repentance may not, in every case, be instantaneous or complete; and in the end, we all run out of time. The authenticity of these stories should be considered one at a time and not in a sweeping fashion.

author: @talongreenlee7704
text:
It‚Äôs almost as if traditions exist for a reason. 

Here‚Äôs a fun thing to think about. Medieval people used to think that swamps were cursed. Eventually some village idiot would say ‚Äúoh that‚Äôs just superstition‚Äù and walk off into the swamp to prove it wasn‚Äôt haunted. Then he‚Äôd drop dead of his own accord with no obvious cause. He wasn‚Äôt pulled into the water by an animal, he wasn‚Äôt hit by a rock or an arrow, he didn‚Äôt die of exhaustion, hunger, thirst, or anything else obvious. If anyone went to check on him, they‚Äôd be walking over the unnaturally, nearly perfectly preserved corpses of anyone else who died in that swamp. That would reinforce the villagers‚Äô beliefs that the swamp was cursed. Turns out people like that died of asphyxiation due to the methane emitted by chemical ridden bog water, which is also what preserved the corpses.

But just remember. No matter how silly sounding the superstition, no matter how wrong the conclusions they came to were, walking off into that swamp will still kill you stone dead.

These people rejecting the nuclear family as the foundational basic structure of civilization are the village idiot who says ‚Äúthat‚Äôs just superstition. Nothing bad will happen to me if I don‚Äôt follow my elders‚Äô advice.‚Äù They‚Äôre at the point where they noticed they‚Äôre tripping over the bodies of people who came before them. They‚Äôre coming to realize their mistakes. They aren‚Äôt dead yet, but they‚Äôre too far in to make it out of the swamp alive at this point.

replies.author: @evilcam
replies.text: Agreed.  Traditions appear to be solutions to problems we forgot existed, because the traditions smoothed it out so well for our ancestors.  When we forget the problem, and no longer understand why we needed the solution, the problem comes back as soon as we abandon that tradition/solution, and we learnt he same hard lessons our ancestors did.  We don't seem to be adapting to them and creating new functional traditions, yet, but perhaps we will on the scale of a few generations worth of time.  Rome wasn't built in a day, and long-standing traditions as solutions to some of our problems won't be rebuilt in a day, or even single generation, either.

replies.author: @Zapp__Brannigan
replies.text:
Catholic apologist and polymath G. K. Chesterton summarized this view with an analogy about a fence in a field.  The modern reformer decries the fence as an obstacle and wants to tear it down to clear the way forward while the intelligent reformer (i.e. the humble one) will argue to preserve it, even if he doesn't know it's purpose:  _"If you don't see the use of it, I certainly won't let you clear it away. Go away and think. Then, when you can come back and tell me that you do see the use of it, I may allow you to destroy it."_

He continues:  _"....until we know what the reason was_ [for the construction of the fence], _we really cannot judge whether the reason was reasonable. It is extremely probable that we have overlooked some whole aspect of the question, if something set up by human beings like ourselves seems to be entirely meaningless and mysterious....nobody has any business to destroy a social institution until he has really seen it as an historical institution. If he knows how it arose, and what purposes it was supposed to serve, he may really be able to say that they were bad purposes, that they have since become bad purposes, or that they are purposes which are no longer served. But if he simply stares at the thing as a senseless monstrosity that has somehow sprung up in his path, it is he and not the traditionalist who is suffering from an illusion."_

author: @kyoai
text:
Pardon me, but most of them chose to go into the industry and freely chose to stay in the industry because they liked the benefits. I find it rather weird how so many actors, be it in porn or normal movies, deliberately and willingly do whatever they need in order to get fame and big money, and then, once they have it, they complain how terrible everything is and how they need drugs and alcohol to endure it. If they did only a few videos and found out that they didn't like the industry and quit, fine, i totally understand that and totally respect that.
But it's weird how some make hundreds of videos over the course of several years, even though everything is supposedly so awful. 
If they really dislike their job to the point where it destroys them emotionally, they should quit, look for something else and let those who enjoy the job do it.
I'm not saying that they are lying or that the industry can not be awful, but I just wonder why the complains usually only come long afterwards, after their fame peaked or after they quit, and why, if it's truly so emotionally destroying, they still chose to stay in the industry for so long. The only real reason I could think of (aside from being forced, which is not what I'm talking about, or that they truly can't find another job to stay afloat, which is not that likely) is that they value fame and easy money over their well-being, in which case I'd say it's on them.

author: @thelastmotel
text:
A lot of British porn stars work for an incredibly short time; much shorter a time than most porn stars from other countries do. There are a lot of British pornstars who work for a week or less, yet still end up somewhat well-known, due to how the British porn industry distribute their content.

I know a woman who did porn for 3 days in the early 90s. During those 3 days, she did over a dozen softcore photoshoots, 7 hardcore porn scenes, that also had a stills photographer taking photos at the same time, and a dozen very short softcore scenes. She basically worked non-stop for 72 hours. She got paid a lot of money for those three days, and then she quit.

The material took almost a decade to be fully released into circulation, and her page on IAFD says that she worked in the industry for 9 years, which isn't close to being true, but that number is based on how long it took to release the material (trickling out material is a very common tactic, particularly in British porn.), and the fact that content was re-used to death on multiple DVD releases.

She still gets recognised to this day, despite being 30 years older, in very different physical shape, and all the porn images of her being from how she looked over a 3 day window.

It still interferes with her life, and she can go for ages being okay, and then just get hit with waves of depression.

No-one should do porn. Male or female. Straight, gay, bi, whatever No-one. Even the ones who do it for a bit and can seem fine, will have gotten some kind of damage from the experience.

Sure. However, I do see a reason people are resorting to get rich quick schemes.
How many people were sold the idea that if they took out a college loan, they would quickly rise the corporate ladder and pay it off fast? How many are stuck at the bottom, being paid crap wages?
Before that, there were often people who graduated HS, worked a job, and moved up the corporate ladder because of skills and reliability. Now we just have MBAs that trash companies and ship everything to China.
If people had upward mobility through a genuine work ethic, maybe better things would happen.

Also, if these stars didn't blow money as fast as they earned it, they probably wouldn't be broke. They could have bought a load of real estate and had a property management company collect rent. They could have bought a bunch of stocks. Instead, they bought mansions, fast cars, and exotic vacations.

author: @LaterLifeLounge
text: As a man who did some porn in my mid-30's in LA, I can tell you it is different for the women. I was friends with Rebecca Wild and did a couple of scenes with her. Nice girl from Iowa.  She didnt come to LA to be a porn star but since she had been a stripper back home, she came out here with hopes to hit it big. She loved the attention, loved her shiny blue Corvette and the money as well. At one point she asked me to be her road manager as she was a headliner and did strip shows and I would run her pyrotechnics. I was tempted but I turned her down. I kept my job as a DJ at a popular club(where I first met her and several others like Debi Diamond, Christy Canyon), and I now realize made the right decision. The male talent is mostly freelance and when I did it, you got 200$ for a scene and that was it. I shot maybe 2-3 scenes per movie.  Porn today is way different than when you were a contract player for a studio. Mostly it's webcams and Onlyfans now. Many can travel and broadcast from anywhere. Here in Thailand, many set up shop because it's dirt cheap to live here. I think because of the internet, it's way to easy to get into porn and make easy money. Just realize at some point, like many here have said, you dont stay young forever. Be working on Plan B. Invest, buy gold, educate yourself. Be independent because that way you dont rely on anyone else for a job. Of course, if you do have kids, you do have a past that might haunt you at some point.
